section1List.hed: The New Butcher's Steaks Are Cheap, Flavorful, and Ready for the Grill
section1List.dek: Go beyond hanger, skirt, and flank steak.
section1List.promoHed: Ask Your Butcher for These Cheap Steak Cuts
section1List.seoTitle: Ask Your Butcher For These Cheap Cuts of Steak
section1List.socialTitle: The Real Cheap, Off-Cuts of Beef You Should Ask for at the Butcher
section1List.body:
When the hell did skirt steak get to be $20 per pound? 

Minimum. Want the local stuff raised without antibiotics and all that jazz? Get ready to pay more.

The reality is that none of the cuts that were considered "cheap" even a few years agowe're talking hanger, skirt, and flank steakare even *affordable* anymore. Meat fans have wised up in a big way to the wonders of these thin, flavorful, and grill-friendly steaks, and butchers have upped the prices to reflect that. 

So, where are the *new* butcher's cuts? 

That's the question we posed to David Diaz, head butcher at [The Meat Hook](http://the-meathook.com/) in Brooklyn, NY. The Meat Hook ain't your average grocery store butcher counter. It's a place that smells of rich, meaty funk in the best, most sanitary way possible. You'll find Diaz behind the counter, breaking down one of the 5-7 whole cows that The Meat Hook brings in every single week. That whole cow thing is the key to offering cuts you've never heard of. Because Diaz isn't getting pre-packaged portions of beef, he's able to offer options that might be less recognizable to most shoppers. The good news? They're just as delicious and much less expensive. 

They may go by other names, but you'll be able to find any of these five true butcher's cuts at a whole animal butcher near you. 

FAUX HANGER
-----------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55687a2e50e46c5c01e99a7a]||||||

+++

You'd think with a name like faux hanger, this steak would be a substitute for hanger steak. Wrong. Diaz and his team recommend it when they run out of skirt steak, or if people come in looking for an alternative. The cut is taken from the bottom sirloin butt, right next to the beef tenderlion. Like skirt steak, it's extremely thin and cooks very quickly, so you'll want to sear this in a very hot pan or cook it on the grill. Faux hanger also benefits from tenderization, so consider tossing it in your [favorite marinade](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/grilled-marinated-sirloin-flap-steaks-350252). You might also see this one labeled as bavette or sirloin tip steak. 

*ENTRAA*
-------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55687a1e5fa91f011a458820]||||||

+++

Nearly every butcher has a different name for this cut, but Diaz and his team refer to it as the *entraa* steak. That's how you'll see it on the menu at Argentinian steakhouses, where it's incredibly popular. This very thin steak has almost no fat and is actually taken off the top of the faux hanger cut. Like its adjacent cut, the *entraa* isn't very tender, so you'll want to marinate this one as well.

OYSTER
------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55687a1e50e46c5c01e999c8]||||||

+++

Surprise: This cut looks like an oyster. Just as with the "oyster" on a chicken, this cut of beef comes from the backbone just above the rump. Unlike the faux hanger and *entraa*, the oyster steak is very tender and, as a result, Diaz warns not to overcook itthings will get chewy quickly. But the oyster steak doesn't lack any flavor thanks to its great fat content.

TOP CAP
-------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55687a0e5fa91f011a45876e]||||||

+++

If you opt for the top cap, you'll want to make sure your butcher trims away most of the fat that surrounds this cut that's taken from the cap of the top round. It's most similar to flank steak and can be seared or served raw as a steak tartare. 

SHOULDER TENDER
---------------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55687a0e50e46c5c01e99916]||||||

+++

Finally there's the shoulder tender. Taken from the cow's shoulder blade, this very tender cut of beef is a much less expensive alternative to filet mignon. You'll also see it labeled as beef shoulder petite tender, bistro filet, or teres major steak. You can pan-sear this guy, or treat it as a small roast and cook it in the oven.
section1List.seoDescription: Go beyond hanger, skirt, and flank steak for the grill.
section1List.socialDescription: Go beyond hanger, skirt, and flank steak.

section1List.dek: How to get a months worth of steak flavor in 10 minutes.
section1List.seoTitle: How to get a months worth of steak flavor in 10 minutes
section1List.seoDescription: We get expert advice on recreating dry-aged flavor
section1List.socialTitle: How to get a months worth of steak flavor in 10 minutes
section1List.socialDescription: We get expert advice on recreating dry-aged flavor

pullQuotes.quote: "Most people are used to eating wet-aged beef. That's what we've become accustomed to."
pullQuotes.attribution: Karl Marsh, executive chef of Omaha Steaks

section1List.body:
Dry-aged beef is a delicious tease. The breakdown of the muscle tissue gives beef a flavor that New York City chef Andrew Carmellini says "wakes up your palate a little bit more." Dry aging removes moisture from the steak and gives it a funky, umami-rich flavor we're nutty about. And while you can [attempt the technique home](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/dry-age-steak-at-home-article), it doesn't come easy.

Dry-aging requires steady humidity and temperature, which are difficult to maintain in a home refrigerator that's opened an [average 50 times a day](http://docs.lib.purdue.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1835&context=iracc). Not to mention that if you're doing any kind of dry-aging, your refrigerator needs to be spotlessany mold or bad flavors in the refrigerator are going straight for the steak. Takeout-flavored ribeye? No, thank you.

But that doesn't mean we don't want the taste of dry-aged steak at home. We spoke to some beef pros who gave us three hacks to mimic a dry-aged steak's flavor.

####Powder Up Your Steak####
Karl Marsh, Executive and Research Chef at [Omaha Steaks](http://www.omahasteaks.com/shop/), loves dry-aged flavor but prefers alternate methods. His beef is wet-aged (keeping beef sealed in the plastic for tenderness) for 21 days, [a number tested meticulously by the University of Nebraska-Lincoln](http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1206&context=animalscinbcr). 

To mimic the dry-aged flavor with a wet-aged steak, season your steaks with a porcini mushroom powder. Find dried porcinis or shiitakes at Asian markets or [online](http://www.kalustyans.com/) and buzz them fast in a food processor before adding to your steak seasoning. Marsh also uses hard cheeses like Parmesan in his seasoning blend. "For most people, this is more palatable than a true dry-aged steak," says Marsh, "It'll create a crust, which a true dry-aged subprimal has." If using cheese in your blend, be sure to use a non-stick skillet instead of grilling grateyou don't want cheese to stick and burn.

####Make Mine with Marinade####
"Dry-aged steak should have big beef flavor but also a funk, which is similar to blue cheese," says Chef Lawrence Knapp of NYC's [Smith & Wollensky](http://www.smithandwollenskynyc.com/), "If you can smell that, you know you have a good beef in front of you."

Take a ribeye and cure the meat's cut side in coarse salt. It'll draw out the moisture, making your dry-aged-esque marinade go right to work. Knapp also recommends using mushrooms with garum, an Italian fish sauce, for the marinade. Add salt, black pepper, and blue cheese around the fat cut side for additional funk. Wrap everything in plastic and let it sit in the refrigerator the day of cooking. 30 days of aging? Psh. You can get Knapp's "fifth element burst of umami" in eight hours.

####Add Something Fishy####
At his New York City restaurant [The Dutch](http://www.thedutchnyc.com/), Carmellini dry ages his steak for 28-30 days, then"re-ages" the trimmed and portioned beef fat cap facing up. Sound complicated? Carmellini is pretty particular about his beef. "It's hard for me to go back and eat a steak that's not aged," says Carmellini. 

That being said, he has a great method for recreating that palate-waking method. "Dry aging forms glutamates, which is kind of a natural MSG," says Carmellini. His quick tip: a glutamate-heavy paste. Take a quality steak from a butcher you trust, and make a paste of anchovies, herbs, and [dehydrated garlic powder](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/secret-trick-best-french-onion-dip-article). Rub some on a day before grilling and then again the day of.

section1List.hed: Get Your Ground Beef Game in Gear
section1List.dek: Master the art of ground beef and make better burgers.
section1List.body:
Pretty soonlike, this weekend  you're going to fire up that grill and throw on a burger or four. So let's talk ground beef.

[#article: /articles/54b80f32ac90eb2c34cfcd6e]||||||

Yes, it's basically just ground meat and fat, and it's uber-popular and versatile (see also: chili, meatloaf, tacos). But there are more distinctions to ground beef than you might realize, not to mention sourcing, food safety, and storage issues to consider.

Master butcher Kari Underlya [James Beard Award-nominated author](http://www.amazon.com/Art-Beef-Cutting-Professionals-Merchandising/dp/1118029577/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1432232047&sr=8-1&keywords=kari%20underly) and owner of the meat industry consulting firm [Range](http://www.rangepartners.com/)has much ground beef wisdom to offer, and she walked us through the basics. 

A key point Underly emphasized more than once: Cook it thoroughly. Below, the wide world of ground beef.

##The Basics##

Ground beef generally consists of the leftover trimmings from steaks, roasts and other beef cuts. At the store, labels will further specify what you're getting."Ground chuck" is made only with chuck trimmings, "ground round" with trimmings from the round and "ground sirloin" with sirloin bits and pieces.

You might see what's called the lean-to-fat ratio. That refers to the makeup of the meat, not its nutritional content, Underly told us "80/20" means a breakdown of 80 percent lean beef to 20 percent fat, typically ground chuck. "85/15" is 85 percent lean and 15 percent fat (ground round) and "90/10" is 90 percent lean and 10 percent fat (ground sirloin).By law, ground beef can have no more than 30 percent fat.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4251119925f464b37aa3e]||||||

##Know the Lingo##

Legally, the USDA "certified organic" label applies to ground beef from livestock raised on organic, pesticide-free feed with access to pasture. They're also free of antibiotics or growth hormones.

The USDA defines grass-fed as cows fed only grass and forage, but that doesnt limit the use of antibiotics, hormones or pesticides nor does it mean the animals were on pasture all the time. Third-party groups that issue their own grass-fed certification include the American Grassfed Association, Food Alliance and Animal Welfare Approved. If USDA approved grass-fed ground beef is what you're after, look for "grass-fed" alongside a "USDA Process Verified" seal.

If you prefer to buy your meat at the farmers market, chances are its in line with, if not exceeding, organic and grass-fed standards, even if not labeled as such. Whichever label is most meaningful to you, ask questions of your meat purveyor or farmer to understand what youre buying.

+++landscape-justified

[#image: /photos/54f89fd1e77a7de9330672b2]||||||

+++

##Beware of Bacteria##

Whilethis probably isn't surprising, theres a difference in ground beef from the grocery store versus your local butcher.

Supermarket ground beef typically comes from many cows, and is ground and packaged somewhere else before it's shipped to the store. "Because they're processing from all these different sources, there's a higher risk for contamination from E. coli," Underly said of supermarket ground beef.

What's sold at a butcher shop is freshly ground in-store, "from one animal, or maybe two to three, not hundreds," she said. This lowers the risk of contamination, but take note: Bacteria can spread no matter where you buy your ground beef. It's imperative to cook it to the USDA-recommended temperature of 160 degrees and use a thermometer to make sure it's hit that point, she said.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4243d6529d92b2c00a4b7]||||||

##Color clues##

In the meat case, ground beef should look a nice cherry red, Underly said. But don't freak out when you unwrap and break the meat apart at home and it looks brownish in the center. Thats just lack of oxygen exposure. On the other hand, ground beef thats already turned brown or gray on the outside could be on its way to spoiled, so avoid it.

Ground beef, or any fresh meat for that matter, should be one of the last things you put in your shopping cart. It needs to stay cold.

##The DIY route##

Not feeling the shrink-wrapped package of ground beef? Some supermarket meat counters will grind whole chuck roast for you, if you ask. Some butcher shops might grind you a custom blend as well.Or if you have the skills and the necessary equipment at home, you could grind it yourself (though the USDA doesn't endorse this).

[#recipe: /recipes/54a434a019925f464b386b91]||||||

##Now and later##

Fresh ground beef has a short shelf lifeone to two days in your fridgeso cook or freeze it within that time.

The meat in those plastic or foam packages in particular sometimes carries a longer "use by" date and will retain a bright-red color for a good week or more. This is because of how its packaged, which can trick you into keeping it around, Underly said. Don't.

Before freezing ground beef, double-wrap it to protect against all that cold air.Underly likes to seal the meat in a zippered freezer bag set inside a second bag, with the meat flattened out. The bags stack easily in the freezer this way and make for quick, even thawing later on.

Well wrapped, ground beef will keep in the freezer for three to six monthsor however long until your next burger craving strikes. Of course, we also had to ask Underly for her take on what makes the best burger. She likes a blend of ground chuck, brisket and bottom round. You're welcome.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a420f16529d92b2c00848d]||||||
section1List.seoTitle: Everything You Need to Know About Ground Beef
section1List.seoDescription: Tips for buying and storing ground beef.

section1List.hed: Can You Dry-Age a Steak at Home?
section1List.dek: No cook knows everythingnot even the pros. So in this new column, we take questions from professional food folks, and find other pros to get the answers. This week: An ice cream slinger seeks the help of a meat man.
section1List.promoHed: How to Dry-Age a Steak at Home
section1List.body:
####Q: "I really love dry-aged rib eye steak. Can I do that at home?"
__Jeni Britton Bauer, Founder & Chief Creative Officer, [Jeni's Splendid Ice Cream](https://jenis.com/)__


####A: "Yeah, you can. But there are certain things to keep in mind..." 
__Rob Levitt, butcher and owner, [The Butcher and Larder](http://thebutcherandlarder.com/), Chicago__

...or pay very close attention to, at least. Mainly temperature and humidity. The fact that most people only have one refrigerator makes dry-aging at home challenging. The more you open your fridge, the more you change the temperature and humidity. If you had a refrigerator that you didnt open at all...if you dedicated a dorm fridge to dry-aging steaks, for example...you could put the steak or roast on a nonreactive plastic or stainless steel rack, or right on the coated rack of the fridge. Close it up and leave it there for five days.

Go to Home Depot and get a temperature/humidity gauge. They're like twenty bucks. You dont want it to be too dry and you certainly dont want it to be too damp. I'd say around 60% humidity is going to be fine. And dont buy a 1-inch ribeye and expect it to age in two weeks. That will just mold. If youre going to go through the trouble of dry-aging at home, make it an event. Tell your butcher you want at least two bones worth, or more, of ribeye. And leave the fat cap on. The fat cap will protect the meat, and after aging, you can peel the cap off, and everything underneath will be nicely aged and preserved.

If you only have one fridge, do it in the crisper drawer and do it for a short period of time. Again, five days is good. Keep it on a nonreactive rack so air can circulate under it. 

Make sure the entire fridge is super-duper clean and sanitized. If there's any mold, the meat will pick it up. Also, be aware that fat absorbs odors and flavors, so if you made soup and put it in the fridge, the steak might soak up all those onion and tomato flavors. Which sounds like it could be good but is actually just really gross. 

For the first timer, if you really want to have some fun with it, go to your butcher shop, get a nice, thick 1-bone ribeye, put it on a nonreactive rack in your crisper drawer, and leave it for a few days. Then buy a new ribeye and cook the two side by side. You can see if theres a difference. And if there is, and you like it, try 10 days next time.

If the meat gets any mold or funk or dryness on it, take a good look at it. If its white mold, or a very pale green, take a towel, dip it in white vinegar and wipe it off. Its not anything to really worry about unless its very fuzzy or weird colors. If mold really creeps you out, you shouldnt be aging steaks in the first place.

I would only do this if you have a good source for meat and a good butcher who can really help you along the way. You're welcome to call me anytime, Jeni. As long as you bring some ice cream.

section1List.hed: The Ultimate Father's Day Steak Buying Guide
section1List.dek: High quality meat for that high quality dad.
section1List.promoHed: The Best Steaks to Order for Dad
section1List.body:
What's the ultimate way to tell your Dad "Thanks for being awesome"? A nice piece of meat. But for Father's Day, the run-of-the-mill meat you buy for weeknight grilling isn't going to cut it. Luckily for you, there's a slew of awesome online sources for such special occasion steaks. 

Here are the steaks he wants, delivered right to his door:

##[Niman Ranch](https://www.nimanranch.com/)##
What started as an 11-acre ranch just outside of San Francisco now has a network of over 700 farms and ranches around the country. Niman Ranch only sells 100% Angus beef that's been raised on a vegetarian diet and free of hormones and antibiotics. Try the hearty [top sirloin](http://store.nimanranch.com/c-22-top-sirloins.aspx) or go for the [Elite Eight Steak Sampler](http://store.nimanranch.com/p-125-the-elite-eight-steak-sampler.aspx) to try a combination of their rib eyes and boneless strip steaks. They deliver Tuesday-Friday only, so order by __Wednesday at 8:00am CST__ for arrival on Friday. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a423fe6529d92b2c00a168]|||
Harissa-Marinated Top Sirloin Tips
|||

##[Heritage Foods USA](http://heritagefoodsusa.com/index.php)##
What makes Heritage Foods USA different from all the rest is that they only sell meat from heritage breed animals. They work with 75 family farms to source rare breedslike Akaushi cattle, which originated in Japan, and Highland cattle, originally from Scotlandthat are in danger of extinction. Splurge on the [Rib Eye Variety Pack](https://store.heritagefoodsusa.com/ribeye-variety-pack-seven-ribeye-steaks-from-four-exquisite-varieties-p1508.aspx), which includes seven steaks from four different breeds, or go for a mix of rib eye, strip, and tenderloin in the [Steak Lover's Package](https://store.heritagefoodsusa.com/steak-lover-package-p1204.aspx). Order no later than __Thursday at 8:00am EST__ for delivery Friday.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4268c6529d92b2c00bf5e]|||
Salt-and-Pepper Rib Eye
|||

##[Greensbury Market](http://www.greensburymarket.com/)##
Everything that Greensbury Market sells is organic and 100% grass-fed. All of the meat is sourced from small farms who pasture-raise their cattle and never give them any antibiotics or synthetic growth hormones. With such high quality standards, it's easy to think that this meat comes at a premium, but it's actually quite affordable. Try the crowd-pleasing [skirt steak](http://www.greensburymarket.com/collections/organic-beef-100-grass-fed/products/organic-100-grass-fed-new-york-strip-steak-10oz) or the lean [top sirloin](http://www.greensburymarket.com/collections/organic-beef-100-grass-fed/products/beef-tenderloin-100-organic-grass-fed-8oz), both of which have been dry-aged for 21 days. They deliver Monday - Wednesday so order by __Tuesday at 6:00pm EST__ for arrival by Wednesday. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a422ea19925f464b37933c]|||
Grilled Skirt Steak with Herb Salsa Verde
|||

##[Flannery Beef](http://www.flannerybeef.com/)##
Based in San Rafael, California, this family-owned operation hasn't changed much since it began in 1963. Their specialty is prime, grain-fed beef that's richly marbled with serious funk and flavor thanks to a 30 to 45 day dry-age. Go for the gift box of rich [California Reserve New York steaks](http://www.flannerybeef.com/butcher/gift-boxes/set-of-2-california-reserve-beef-new-york-steaks.html) or the impressive [Midwestern porterhouse](http://www.flannerybeef.com/butcher/prime-beef/midwestern/midwestern-beef-porterhouse-steak.html). Order by __Wednesday at 11:00am PT__ for delivery Friday.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4205119925f464b377c8f]|||
Porterhouse Steak with Herbed Butter
|||

section1List.seoTitle: How to Defrost Frozen Beef, Chicken, Fish, and Other Meats
section1List.socialTitle: How to Defrost Frozen Meat, Fish, and Other Proteins
section1List.body:
The freezer is one of our favorite assets in the kitchen. We've constantly got ours stocked with frozen sausages, fish, ground beef, and other proteins that make quick weeknight meals in a pinch, all without having to run to the grocery store. 

There's just one thing: Integrate a freezer pantry into your home cooking and you'll need to become a defrosting pro. Yes, cooking directly from frozen is *technically* an option, but doing can result in watery protein and an overall loss of quality.

Essentially, you've got three choices when it comes to safely thawing protein. Which one you choose comes down to how much time you have. 

IDEAL: The Refrigerator
-----------------------
Say you've got all the time in the world and really planned ahead for tomorrow night's dinner. If that's the case, the absolute best and safest way to defrost your frozen meat is in the refrigeratoryour meat will defrost at a consistent temperature that's below the [USDA's magical safety mark of 40 F](http://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/food-safety-education/get-answers/food-safety-fact-sheets/safe-food-handling/the-big-thaw-safe-defrosting-methods-for-consumers/CT_Index). 

Simply place your meateither in its plastic packaging, or removed and covered with plastic wrapon a plate in your fridge the night before you plan on cooking it. The plate ensures that any moisture produced during the thawing process doesn't end up all over your fridge. Check back the next night and you'll find perfectly thawed pieces of chicken, fish, or steak ready to get seasoned and cooked. If you're working with a larger piece of meat like a whole chicken or a roast-size cut of beef you'll want to allow more time to ensure the meat thaws all the way through. 

Really want to get ahead? Ground meat, stew meat, poultry, and seafood will be safe in the fridge for an additional day or two after defrosting; beef, pork or lamb roasts, chops and steaks can keep for 3 to 5 days. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4231219925f464b379444]||||||

IN A PINCH: Cold Water
-------------------------
More often than not, this is the situation: We get home from work and need to get dinner on the table in less than an hour. In these cases, place your protein in a resealable bag and submerge it in a large bowl of cold tap water. Just as with the refrigerator method, thawing times depend on the size of the protein. Small items like sausage, boneless chicken breasts, and thin cuts of steak such as skirt will defrost within an hour. Thawing larger cuts will take 2 to 3 hours, and you'll need to change out the water every hour to ensure things stay cold. 

If you have a change of plans and decide you don't want that chicken breast you've been defrosting in cold water for dinner, make sure you cook it through before putting it back in the fridge or refreezing.


[#recipe: /recipes/54a4254719925f464b37acae]||||||



EMERGENCY SITUATION: The Microwave
----------------------------------
Finally, if you're completely out of options and in desperate need of some meat, your microwave is an option. Remove the protein from its plastic packaging, place it on a clean plate, and consult your microwave's defrost capabilities. While most modern microwaves come with supposedly "smart" defrost settings, these can still lead to partially cooked food and a less-than-ideal rubbery texture during the thawing process. To make sure this doesn't happen to you, keep a close eye on your protein while it's in the microwave, stopping to check the defrosting progress every 45 seconds or so. 

Like the cold water method, anything defrosted in the microwave should be cooked immediately before being refrigerated or refrozen. 

[#recipe: /recipes/5509b2623f2f10b26908820a]||||||

section5List.socialDescription: Competition for the best burger in London has gone mad. Some burgers are gourmet and piled high with toppings, whereas others are thinner, simpler, wrapped in paper, steamy and sloppy. All I can say is my insanity burger is going to be right up therethe method is almost ritualistic in what it requires you to do to get close to burger perfection. I've also used the brilliant technique of brushing the burgers with mustard and a dash of Tabasco Chipotle sauce as they cook to build up an incredible gnarly layer of seasoning.

fields.title: Beer-Steamed Clams

section5List.dek:
You can infuse your shellfish with smoky flavor (and keep the smells out of the house) by throwing it on the grill. 
 The lobster, shrimp and clams here are meant to be cooked at the same time and served with three sauces for mixing and matching. If you make the sauces in advance, the mixed grill comes together in less than a half hour.  
 For a simpler dinner, you can absolutely make one type of seafood and one of the sauces; just make sure to increase the quantities as needed.
section5List.promoDek: A grilled shellfish dinner is a great summer weekend project. Use any type of seafood you like and adjust the quantities as needed.

section5List.dek: You've been doing it in the car when nobody's looking...but you don't have to hide anymore. It's time to come cleanand this finger-licking-good burger is so much more satisfying than those greasy drive-through hockey pucks. Plus grass-fed beef is leaner and lower in calories than conventional beef. It even contains a unique fat that may help prevent cancer, diabetes, and heart disease. Talk about an afternoon delight.

section5List.dek:
Few travel experiences are more American than eating dessert at a roadside diner. My order? A slice of banana cream pie: the topping
whipped high, the creamy filling offering comfort far from home. To elevate this classic in my own kitchen, I add sliced bananas to the hot
(and simple) custard to infuse it with flavor. And did I mention chocolate's involved? It's my take on diner deluxe. Janet Taylor McCracken
section5List.promoDek:

whipped high, the creamy filling offering comfort far from home...

section5List.dek: Does anything say straight-up summer like a cobbler? The one here gains complexity from a jumble of different berries and extra depth from dark brown sugar. Mixing the brown sugar with regular granulated sugar makes it easier to sprinkle on top of the biscuit topping before the cobbler goes into the oven; when it comes out, the tender, featherlight biscuits will be crowned by golden crunch.

section2List.hed: Everything You Need to Know About Buying Charcoal
section2List.dek: From basic briquettes to that restaurant-grade stuff imported from Japan.
section2List.promoHed: Your Summer Grilling Guide to Charcoal
section2List.body:
You've polished your grill, stocked up on steaks, and set a bucket of beer at your feet. Summer's about to start, just as soon as you get the fire started. Luckily, the last stepgrabbing a bag of charcoalis the easiest. Right?

Sort of. One stroll through the outdoor cooking aisle reveals that there's a whole slew of charcoal options availableclassic briquettes, hardwood, and instant-this-or-that. Which gives the best burn? Which gives the best flavor? Below, we sort through the ashy madness. 


HARDWOOD LUMP CHARCOAL
----------------------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5579eb8b81ac1e5023674d20]||||||

+++

This is your best case scenario. The stuff's made from real chunks of charred hardwood and will give you the cleanest burn with the purest flavor possiblewhile remaining firmly within the economical camp. Plus, because it's *actual* wood, anything you grill will pick up a whiff of that smokey flavor. Just make sure to look for "100% All Natural" and "Hardwood Lump Charcoal" on the packaging and you'll be set. 

__What to Buy:__ [Royal Oak All Natural Hardwood Lump Charcoal](http://www.amazon.com/Royal-Oak-195228071-Charcoal-8-8-Pound/dp/B007JNBNNE)

BINCHOTAN
---------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5579a96574cbe9ed7c20a526]||||||

+++

Peer into the back of many high-end restaurant kitchens and you'll spot a small Japanese-style hibachi grill loaded with what looks like charred branches plucked straight out of the forest. That burnt gold is *binchotan*, Japan's answer to charcoal briquettes. *binchotan*'s superpower? It lasts incredibly long. Whether you opt for the more expensive white charcoal (known as *kamitosa* or *kishu*) or the more budget-friendly *aramaru*, you're looking at a fire that will last for 3-5 hours. It also burns at extremely high temperatures, ensuring quick sears for meat and fish. 

__What to Buy:__ [Korin *Binchotan* Aramaru Charcoal](http://korin.com/Binchotan-Aramaru-Charcoal)  

THAI CHARCOAL
-------------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5579e5bb74cbe9ed7c20ad5b]||||||

+++

[Pok Pok](http://www.pokpokny.com/home/) chef Andy Ricker wanted to capture the high heat and long burn times of *binchotan*, but without the high price tag or ecological issues (much of the *binchotan* imported to the US comes from the [endangered mangroves](http://wwf.panda.org/about_our_earth/blue_planet/coasts/mangroves/mangrove_threats/) of Malaysia, ). So Ricker did what any superstar chef would do: he developed his own charcoal. His uses rambutan wood, a sustainable product that burns nearly as hot and as long as *binchotan*, but for a fraction of the price. 

__What to Buy:__ [Pok Pok Thaan Charcoal](http://www.amazon.com/Pok-PokThaan-Thaan-Charcoal/dp/B00R8HILG8)

CHARCOAL BRIQUETTES
-------------------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5579a96574cbe9ed7c20a524]||||||

+++

This is probably the charcoal you grew up with. Briquettes are compressed, perfectly uniform, and sold at every hardware store, gas station, and grocery store in America. But what exactly are they made of? There's wood, but charcoal briquettes also contain [a bunch of other ingredients](http://old.cbbqa.org/wood/Kingsford.html), such as starch, sodium nitrate, sawdust, and borax. It's nothing that's going to hurt you, but it's not going to give you the smokey flavor of hardwood charcoal, either.

__What to Buy:__ [Kingston Original](http://www.amazon.com/Kingsford-30524-Charcoal-Briquets-13-9-Pound/dp/B0086TBA74/ref=sr_1_5?s=lawn-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1434034463&sr=1-5)

INSTANT CHARCOAL BRIQUETTES
---------------------------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5579a94a81ac1e5023674683]||||||

+++

Unless your choice is between building a fire with these or not building a fire at all, instant charcoal briquettes should be avoided. Sure, they're easy to light, but only because they've been presoaked in lighter fluid, which lends a less-than-desirable, chemically-laced aftertaste to everything around it.

BONUS: FIRESTARTER LIGHTER CUBES
--------------------------------
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5579a94981ac1e5023674677]||||||

+++

If you happen to come across these, do yourself a favor and run in the opposite direction. Why? They're loaded with all sorts of synthetic chemicals and additives. Plus, they're completely unnecessarygrab a [simple chimney starter](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000WEOQV8/ref=pd_lpo_sbs_dp_ss_1?pf_rd_p=1944687662&pf_rd_s=lpo-top-stripe-1&pf_rd_t=201&pf_rd_i=B001AN7RGG&pf_rd_m=ATVPDKIKX0DER&pf_rd_r=0A6H4Z1MH5TCAM930CN9), half a newspaper, and the charcoal of your choice instead.
section2List.seoTitle: Everything You Need to Know About Buying Charcoal
section2List.seoDescription: How to buy charcoal, briquettes, binchotan and other grilling needs.
section2List.socialTitle: Everything You Need to Know About Buying Charcoal
section2List.socialDescription: From basic briquettes to that restaurant-grade stuff imported from Japan.

section2List.hed: How to Turn Your Kettle Grill into a Smoker
section2List.promoHed: How to Turn Your Kettle Grill into a Smoker
section2List.body:
Summer was made for grilling. Red-hot charcoal, hot dogs, burgers, the obligatory limp, grilled eggplant (hey, some of our best friends are vegetarian). 

But what about true *barbecue*. The type of slow and low cooking that's characterized by billowing plumes of smoke at 9-hour cook times. How do we do *that* at home?

In his new book *[Feeding the Fire](http://www.amazon.com/Feeding-Fire-Strategies-Barbecue-Grilling-ebook/dp/B00N2A6HO8/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1432235479&sr=1-1&keywords=feeding%20the%20fire)*, NYC chef and restaurateur Joe Carroll and writer Nick Fauchald break down the separate and often misunderstood art forms of barbecue and grilling. While there are plenty of great tips for those looking to get their grill on, it's Carroll's smoking advice we really wanted. After all, the man produces award-winning 'cue at his smoked meat meccas in Brooklyn and Philadelphia, [Fette Sau](http://www.fettesaubbq.com/). 

That's great and all, but there's one problem: Like a lot of people, we don't have a smoker. 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/555e25e8100d9bda6d8220aa]||||||

+++

Luckily, Carroll's book gives us the blueprint for smoking in something that most people already have and anyone can [buy for less than $100](http://www.amazon.com/Weber-741001-Silver-One-Touch-22-Inch/dp/B00004RALU)a simple charcoal kettle grill.

The biggest hurdle to summertime smoking for most home cooks is not having a dedicated smokerthey're expensive, bulky, and yet another piece of cooking equipment. But they seem especially redundant if you already have a perfectly acceptable charcoal kettle grill sitting around.   Well, good news: "Kettle grills make pretty good smokers," says Carroll. You just need a few pointers on how to set them up for barbecue success.

##Turn your kettle grill into a smoker##
It's easy. First, be sure to thoroughly clean out all ash and debris from the bottom of the grill before you do anything. From there, use a [chimney starter](http://www.amazon.com/Weber-7416-Rapidfire-Chimney-Starter/dp/B000WEOQV8) to heat up your [hardwood lump charcoal](http://www.webstaurantstore.com/royal-oak-natural-wood-lump-charcoal-8-kg-bag/688CLUMP8K.html?utm_source=amazon-pads&utm_medium=cpc&utm_term=688CLUMP8K) just as you would if were grilling. Once they're ready, remove the grate and dump the charcoal one side of the grill and place a disposable aluminum tray on the other. Place a few hardwood chunks (more on that in a second) over the coals, replace the grate, and place your meat on the grill over the pan. 

Using a [grill thermometer](http://www.amazon.com/bbq-factory-CHARCOAL-SMOKER-THERMOMETER/dp/B008N5JMEY/ref=zg_bs_3563990011_7), monitor the heat of your DIY smokeryou want to stay between 200F and 225F. If things get too hot, close the top vent. On the other hand, if the temperature drops too low, add a few pieces of unlit hardwood charcoal. 

(The only problem with using your kettle grill as a smoker is that you have to remove the top of it to add more charcoal and wood, which will cause smoke and heat to escape. This means your meat might take a bit longer to smoke, but shouldn't be too much of an issue if you work quickly and efficiently.)

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/555e25e8644d45515b759d10]||||||

+++

SCORE WOOD CHIPS FOR MORE FLAVOR
------------------
[Wood chips](http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=sr_nr_n_2?fst=as%3Aoff&rh=n%3A2972638011%2Cp_4%3AWeber%2Cn%3A%213238155011%2Cn%3A553760%2Cn%3A13299251%2Cn%3A9001145011%2Cn%3A9001148011&bbn=9001145011&ie=UTF8&qid=1432239454&rnid=9001145011), it turns out, are an incredibly important part of the smoking universe. Charcoal will give your food smokiness, but wood adds an extra layer of depth. But you'll want to choose your wood wisely. For example, while mesquite might be the most widely available, its aggressive, bitter flavor might not be exactly what you're looking for. 

Instead, look to milder smoking woods: Consider cherry or apple if you want to impart a gentle sweetness; maple and pecan for a medium amount of smoky essence; and woods like hickory, oak, and walnut for an unmistakable pungent smokiness (just use those woods in smaller amounts).

MAKE A KILLER SPICE RUB
-----------------------
Want to define your your own personal style of 'cue? The best place to start is with your spice rub. Carroll bases most of his menu on his house blend. "We use this rub on just about everything that we smoke," writes Carroll. His version uses dark brown sugar, salt, ground espresso, black pepper, garlic powder, cinnamon, cumin, and cayenneand works great as a starting point point for your own. Want a spicier smoked meat? Up the amount of cayenne and cut down on the sugar. Looking to add a Cajun or North African bent to your brisket? Check out more ideas [right here](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-spice-blends-article). 

DON'T SKIP THE BARBECUE CHICKEN
-------------------------------------
So you've hacked your kettle grill into a smoker, made your own house spice rub, and bought some fancy new wood chips. Now it's time to smoke something. We love Carroll's dead-simple dry rub-brined chicken. "Barbecue chicken is so common that we often overlook it," writes Carroll. "But when done well, it's one of my very favorites." That dry rub you concocted? It's going flavor the chicken in the form of a simple brine, which will keep things juicy. No time for a 4- to 8-hour brine? Just coat the chicken in the stuff, toss it on the smoker, and call it a day. Either way, you can't lose.  

[#recipe: /recipes/555ddcd4644d45515b759349]||||||
section2List.seoTitle: How to Turn Your Kettle Grill into a Smoker
section2List.socialTitle: How to Turn Your Kettle Grill into a Smoker

section2List.dek: Don't have time for homemade sauce? That doesn't mean you can't make something delicious.
section2List.promoHed: Turn Bottled Barbecue Sauce Into Something Much Better
section2List.seoTitle: How to Make Bottled Barbecue Sauce Much Better
section2List.seoDescription: Amp up bottled barbecue sauce with these add-ins.
section2List.socialDescription: Don't have time for homemade sauce? That doesn't mean you can't make something delicious.
section2List.body:
A long time ago I learned how to make a quick barbecue sauce by basically spicing up ketchup. The results were so easy and tasty that I never bothered to learn how to make the real stuff from scratch.

[#article: /articles/552d13ba20ca5d650ed24129]||||||

How simple are we talking? Super simple: Caramelize a chopped onion and garlic, add ketchup and some spices like dried mustard and ground cayenne, some brown sugar, coffee, and bourbon. Let the whole thing simmer for a half hour, pure it with a stick blender, and you're good to go.

But then I got thinking: couldn't I start with a flavorful bottle of barbecue sauce instead of ketchup to yield a more smoky, tangy flavor in even less time? Yes. Whether it's a bottle of your favorite barbecue joint's sauce or something you grabbed in a rush in the grocery store, it's easy to simply stir in more flavor. 

If you have a little time, cook down the mix with some traditional flavors. Looking for something faster? Since bottled sauce already starts out on the right track, you can simply up the flavor by mixing in any of these ingredients. Either way, it'll taste so good, your friends will think you made it from scratch.


+++landscape


[#image: /photos/54b2fd7311c5d6af478b690b]||||||




+++

##For Maximum Flavor: Caramelized Onions and Garlic##

The classic barbecue sauce ingredients are classic for a reasonthey yield delicious results. Create a twice-cooked effect by adding caramelized onions to bottled sauce (and mustard and hot sauce if you like) and cooking it down a second time.

##For Smoke: Chipotle##

A lot of [barbecue sauces](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/mesa-barbecue-sauce-358869) rely on dried chile peppers to create a smoky, deep heat. An easy way to bring this flavor to a bottled sauce? Add jarred [chipotle peppers in adobo sauce](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002N3XZ6I/ref=pd_lpo_sbs_dp_ss_1) to taste. Chop them and stir in for chunky texture, or use a stick blender to create a smooth sauce.

##For Seafood: Old Bay##

Grilling seafood? Why not combine the classic seaside shack spice with your sauce, creating the ultimate [glaze for shrimp](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/grilled-shrimp-with-honey-ginger-barbecue-sauce-51108030) or a great topping for smoky crab cake sandwiches.

##For Deep Spice: Harissa##

We're big fans of the [tomato paste plus harissa combo](http://www.epicurious.com/ingredients/modern-pantry-essentials-gallery/2). Go one step further and mix the hearty flavors of barbecue sauce with the North African chile paste to create rich spicy undertones, perfect for spreading on buns or tossing with grilled meats.

##For Bright Tang: Fruit Juice##

Like your barbecue sauce on the sweet, tangy side? Stir in some orange, pineapple, lime, or lemon juice (or a combination) to help give it that [tart, fruity flavor](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/orange-maple-pork-ribs-97).

##For Sweet Depth: Jam##

Want even more fruit flavor? Stir in some jam for a tasty, sweet-savory take. Most flavors work here, including orange marmalade, [peach preserves](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/grilled-pork-tenderloin-with-peach-barbecue-sauce-230636), and raspberry jam. This would be particularly delicious used as a glaze on a slow-cooked meat like pork shoulder or ribs.

fields.caption: Grilled Shrimp with Honey-Ginger Barbecue Sauce
fields.promoTitle: Grilled Shrimp with Honey-Ginger Barbecue Sauce
fields.title: Grilled Shrimp with Honey-Ginger Barbecue Sauce

section2List.hed: How to Make an Amazing Spice Rub Out of Almost Anything
section2List.dek: If you've got anything even resembling a spice rack, you've got the means to make a mean rub.
section2List.promoHed: The Secret to Great Barbecue: Rub It In
section2List.body:
This summer, people all around the country will chase the dream of perfectly grilled meats. And though they may get the grill to just the right temperature and [buy the best steaks](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/the-new-butcher-s-steaks-are-cheap-flavorful-and-ready-for-the-grill-article) they can find, sometimes the meat will still taste...bland.

Therein lies the rub.

What these grillers need is a good spice rub. Used before grilling, rubs amp up meats and give their outside a blackened, crisp char. And they're almost laughably easy to make at home, so you can customize it to your taste. Or, for that matter, to the taste of any avid griller in your life (hey, Father's Day is just around the corner).

Here's how to get your rub down.

####Scour the Pantry####
Chances are, you have every component of a barbecue rub within arms reach, because most rubs are simply mixes of common pantry spices. Any spice is fair game, but we're particularly big fans of cumin's smokiness and the way paprika transforms when heated on the grill. Toast seeds and whole spices like coriander and cinnamon to give your meats extra nuttiness. Heck, you could even [make your own onion and garlic powders](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/secret-trick-best-french-onion-dip-article) for some extra punch. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a420726529d92b2c0080cb]||||||

####Take a Coffee Break####
Coffee is a secret weapon for a lot of dishes: [ham biscuits](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/country-ham-with-redeye-gravy-56389462), [braised short ribs](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/coffee-braised-short-ribs-with-ancho-chile-230930), and, yes, rubs. In [its dried, ground form](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/coffee-paprika-salt-51178690), coffee adds a bitter and vaguely chocolatey component to meat rubsjust combine with salt, pepper, and some brown sugar. Its great to use [on burgers](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/coffee-rubbed-cheeseburgers-with-texas-barbecue-sauce-353870), [in brisket](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/turkish-coffee-rubbed-brisket-51250890), and any other dish that needs a little waking up.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a42e3c6529d92b2c012139]||||||


####A Salty Suggestion####
For extra crunch and flavor-boosting, use some custom-made salts as part of your rub. Go crazy with a mouth-numbingly spicy [Sichuan-sesame salt](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/sichuan-sesame-salt-51178700). And don't limit your rubs for beefa celery seed salt can be *so* choice on some fish. Likewise, a paprika-rich rub brings the heat in some [mahi-mahi tacos](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/grilled-mahi-mahi-tacos-366731).

[#recipe: /recipes/54a422b06529d92b2c0094ce]||||||

####~~Best~~ Zest Dad Ever####
Okay, we exaggerated: Not everything you need for a dynamite rub can be found in your pantry. In the past, we've recommended [using fruits and herbs to make salts](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-diy-salts-and-sugars-from-fruit-herbs-and-vegetables-article), and it's not totally off-base to use them in a rub. Snatch some citrus from your fruit basket and get to zesting for a citrus-flecked rub. Grilling steak for fajitas? Don't think twice about using a puckery [chipotle-lime salt](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/chipotle-lime-salt-51179410) or [this lemon-pepper salt](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/lemon-pepper-salt-rub-51104430) on bluefish. It seems fancy, but anybody can do it. Even a dad.


[#recipe: /recipes/54a422ae6529d92b2c0094c3]||||||
section2List.seoTitle: Why You Should Be Making Barbecue Rubs
section2List.seoDescription: Recipes for easy spice rubs you can make at home.
section2List.socialTitle: Why You Should Be Making Barbecue Rubs
section2List.socialDescription: If you've got anything even resembling a spice rack, you've got the means to make a mean rub.
